Dear Mr. Hawkins:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,

ALLEGATION:
Youth is constantly getting into fights with other youth at the facility. Youth is often
being hit and choked by other youth. Youth has reached out to staff about this
matter, but staff respond that there is nothing they can do.
2

INVESTIGATION:
Director was interviewed on November 15, 2021, face to face at the facility. Director
reported Youth C has been targeting Youth A and Youth B. Director described
Youth C attacking other youth without warning or being provoked for unknown
reasons, the attacks have focused on Youth A and Youth B. Youth C was described
as being calm and getting along with her peers and then without warning attacking
peers. Director reported he has witnessed this behavior from Youth C and has
watched staff intervene immediately to keep Youth A and Youth B safe from Youth
C. Director reported staff intervene by stepping in-between Youth C and other youth
or restrain Youth C when needed to keep other youth and as well as Youth C safe.
Director stated Youth C is currently hospitalized for her behaviors. Youth C has a
safety plan as well as a 1:1 staff assignment. The safety plan was described by
Director as more of a safety plan for Youth C because of her behaviors not for the
other youth in the facility.
Youth A was interviewed on November 15, 2021, face to face at the facility. Youth A
reported Youth C attacks people when upset. Youth A described Youth C attacking
Youth A, Youth B and staff. Youth A reported Youth C recently tried choking him
(Youth A is a female but identifies as a male) with the hood of the shirt he was
wearing for no reason. Youth A stated he was sitting down, had not said anything to
Youth C and Youth C walked behind Youth A and pulled Youth A’s hood of the shirt
he was wearing, choking Youth A. Youth A stated staff were in the room with Youth
C and responded immediately to get Youth C off Youth A. Youth A reported he feels
safe at the facility and staff try and keep Youth C away from her peers.
Youth B was interviewed on November 15, 2021, face to face at the facility. Youth B
reported getting along with Youth C well at first but recently stated Youth C has been
attacking Youth A and Youth B for “no reason.” Youth B stated Youth C took Youth
B’s glasses off her face and pulled Youth B’s hair and choked Youth B once with
Youth B’s hood. Youth B described staff as “getting in Youth C’s way but they don’t
always get there in time.” Youth B stated Youth C will “be fine then will not be.”
Youth B stated staff are doing their job “to keep kids safe.” Youth B reported Youth
C is currently not at the facility and is hopeful that Youth C will not return.
Staff 1 was interviewed on November 24, 2021, by telephone. Staff 1 works with
Youth A, Youth B and Youth C. Staff 1 described Youth C as being “spontaneous
and random” when attacking Youth B and/or Youth C. Staff 1 described Youth C as
walking by Youth A, who was sitting reading a book not interacting with Youth C at
all, and Youth C grabbing Youth A. Staff 1 reported there was no indication Youth C
was going to attack Youth A. Staff 1 stated when that occurred staff immediately
restrained Youth C to protect Youth A. Staff 1 stated if there is any indication Youth
C is upset or going to attack a peer, staff step between Youth C and the other youth.
Staff 1 described instances where staff try to distract Youth C or get her involved in
different activities when staff know Youth C is upset. Staff 1 reported there are also
times when staff have the other youth leave the area if Youth C is escalating. Staff 1
stated, “sometimes it happens so quick, you’re like what’s going on.” Staff 1 denied
3

ever witnessing staff allowing Youth C to physically attack another youth without
intervening.
Staff 2 was interviewed on November 24, 2021, by telephone. Staff 2 works with
Youth A, Youth B and Youth C. Staff 2 reported Youth C recently started attacking
peers, normally Youth C’s behaviors were of self-harming. Staff 2 described Youth
C as “out of blue going after a peer.” Staff 2 stated all of the youth can be sitting in
the living room, relaxing, working on projects, all getting along, and Youth C will walk
over to Youth A or Youth B and attack without warning. Staff 2 stated staff intervene
immediately by getting between Youth C and the youth when Youth C is physically
attacking other youth. Staff 2 reported at times Youth C is restrained in order to
protect the youth that is being attacked by Youth C.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
 Safety Plan for Youth C – Outlines action plan for Youth C and staff crisis
response.
 Critical Incident/Adverse Event Report From dated 11/07/2021 – describes
Youth C walking over and attacking Youth A, staff intervened to stop Youth
C’s behavior.
 Incident Report 125830183 dated 11/07/2021 describes Youth C attacking
Youth A unprovoked and staff restraining Youth C.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
The licensee shall have a sufficient number of
administrative, supervisory, social service, direct care, and
other staff on duty to perform the prescribed functions
required by these administrative rules and in the agency's
program statement and to provide for the continual needs,
protection, and supervision of residents.
ANALYSIS: The facility is found in compliance as Youth A and Youth B
reported that staff intervene when Youth C’s behaviors are
escalating and when Youth C attacks her peers.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
The licensing authority, DCWL, was not notified of Youth C being hospitalized on
November 9, 2021.
INVESTIGATION:
Director was interviewed on November 15, 2021, face to face at the facility. Director
reported Youth C was hospitalized last week and has not returned to the facility.
Director acknowledged the notification to DCWL was overlooked.
4

DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
 Incident Report 126410182 dated 11/17/2021 – describing Youth C being
hospitalized on 11/09/2021.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4150 Incident reporting.
(1) Any incident resulting in serious injury of a resident or
illness requiring inpatient hospitalization, shall be reported
to the parent/ legal guardian, responsible referring agency,
and the licensing authority as soon as possible, but not
more than 24 hours after the incident.
ANALYSIS: The facility is found in noncompliance for failing to notify DCWL
that Youth C was hospitalized.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, I recommend no changes in
the license status.
